Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 01:51AM Juliecc wrote: JCinAZ, is your excisional on Wednesday or Thursday because before you said it was the 26th which is Wednesday!  ~ Playing mom here and making sure you show up on the right day :-)
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 10:12AM Juliecc wrote: I had my surgery 2 days ago and it went so much better than I thought it would!  The lidocaine shot for the wire hurt but it was just a little bit uncomfortable after that.  Then they taped it down.  I had over a 4 hour gap til surgery and I didn't feel the wire at all.  I posted my experience in the pleomorphic calcifications thread and I'm pasting it here for you.  The recovery has been great.  Less pain than my stereotactic!  They took my phone away in the pre op room. Here it is: The play by play of my excisional biopsy:  By the way I had a headache all day probably due to no caffeine, water, or food.  They did the wire localization in a mammogram room with a rolling chair.  There were 3 people there.  They did all mammogram compressions while I was sitting.  They took a couple of views and then while compressed, gave me a lidocaine shot.  They then inserted the hollow needle and took a couple more mammo views.  I felt tugging when they played with the needle but not pain.  It took them a few minutes to get the needle right where they wanted it.  Then they stuck the wire in and took 2 more views.  They put the needle through the side even though my stereo was through the top.  They taped the wire down with a gauze pad on top and a lady walked me to the elevators and up to the surgery floor.  I was offered a blanket and I took it because it was freezing there!  I had to wait 45 minutes or more in the waiting room until a pre op bed was available. I had my own little room for pre op where I'd spend the next 4 hours!  I had my vitals taken, medical history questions asked, went to the bathroom twice, they did a urine pregnancy test, and then they inserted an IV (no drugs just fluids).  I took about a 2 hour nap which was awesome! Finally 1 and a half hours past my scheduled time, the surgeon came in the see if I had any questions.  Then the anesthesiologist came in and I told him I wanted twighlight sleep.  Everyone was fine with that. Next a nurse put a shot in my IV to relax me (verced I think).  Then I got wheeled to the OR.  I noticed it was big and drab.  There were 3 people across the room fiddling with equipment.  After that, I don't remember a thing!  I don't remember the surgeon walking in or seeing the anesthesiologist.  I don't remember being wheeled to recovery either.  It was fantastic.  I stayed there for 45 minutes and they gave me apple juice.  My sister in law showed up to take me home.  I was fully alert and dressed myself with no problem.  I only have a 4 by 4 inch gauze pad covered by an even bigger square piece of tape,  I can't take a real shower for 48 hours!  We went through a drive through and I devoured a chicken sandwich.  I was starving!  I don't have hardly any pain right now but I think I'll fill my vicoden prescription just in case. The surgeon didn't mark the box about using ice packs but I am anyway!  I hope that's ok.  I didn't even see the surgeon afterward but a nurse said he said it all went well.  No pain yet but I remember my breast starting to ache 5 hours after the stereotactic biopsy.  It was tolerable though.  I think that's it!  I finally got my first surgery ever out of the way :-)
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 10:33AM Juliecc wrote: By the way, the recovery has been excellent!  I drove my self to CVS that night (3 hours later) to fill my Vicoden prescription in case I needed it.  The next morning I drove the kids to school and went out with the boyfriend that night (the day after).  I only used an ice pack a couple of times that day for good measure but it only ached a tad when I leaned forward,  I'll use ice a little today to avoid bruising.  I have a big gauze pad on the area that I can take off today to take a real shower.  The stera strips stay on for a few days.  The surgeon said I'd have dissolvable stitches.  I peaked under the gauze this morning to see the incision but there are so many stera strips that I can't see it.  The incision is along the top of my areola.  This was so much easier than my stereotactic when my breast was sore for about 3 days.  I took Thursday (surgery day) and Friday off and will return to work on Monday.  I hope it goes easy for you, Monday!  I was so nervous but it really was a good experience.
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 10:30AM Juliecc wrote: I'm happy you did well!  I'm sure your relieved it's over.  Don't be surprised if your breast turns all sorts of pretty colors in the next few days!  5 days later I'm a little sore and swollen but it's been fine.
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 05:53PM - edited Aug 12, 2009 05:54PM by Juliecc Thanks for the statistics clarification, Leaf.  That's reassuring. Mel,  I'll definitely report back how the surgery went.  It isn't until 3:30 on the 20th (California time).  I just had my pre-op labs done (blood, urine and EKG). I didn't learn too much more from the pre-op.  He said that 5% or less come back showing cancer.  I can choose to have IV sedation if I want but even if it's general, he said they won't stick a tube down my throat.  My brother, an anesthesiologist, confirmed this.  He said he'd make the incision along my arreola even though the area is a good 2 inches above that.  Dissolvable stitches.  I asked if he'd remove about the size of a grape and he said a little bit more than that so if they did find somethink, I'd be less likely to have to have another surgery.  No food 10 hours before, and no drink for 8 hours before.  I'm doing good about not stressing too much.  It's a simple and short surgery.My motto right now is "just show up" :-)  I asked him if I could plan on going to dinner and a movie the next day and he said yes, I'll feel totally fine.  I asked about walking on a treadmill and he said to just wait a couple a days.  5 days for weights.  I think I'll wait a little longer than that!  Recovery doesn't sound that much more difficult than the biopsy but I didn't have the hematomas like you did.  That's a bummer. Let me know what your doctors say!
Posts.Title: Radial Scar ?'s cemjo3 marie5890

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 06:47AM - edited Aug 12, 2009 06:53AM by Juliecc I also have a radial star that I am having excised next Thursday (first surgery).  I had a small cluster of calcifications and from the stereotactic biopsy I had no atypia but the report did say columnar cell alteration and radial scar.  One of the docs called the pathologist and I guess there was part of one in one core - a very small one since it didn't show up on mammogram.  ( I had 12 cores removed, vacuum assisted, 9 gauge needle).  I've read studies that when there is no atypia, there is about a 4% chance of something malignant nearby.  I also read in one study that when 12 or more samples are taken, no malignancies were found.  I read that this might double our future risk of BC whether it's removed or not since our breasts made these radial scars in the first place.  Here were the recommendations of 3 breast doctors: 1. Dr. #1 who did the stereotactic biopsy - "If it were my wife, I'd tell her to have a follow up mammogram in 6 months.  I've never seen one of these come back positive in my 20 years of doing this.  If it does, I'll buy you a steak dinner (ha ha).  But if you do decide to remove it, that wouldn't be wrong because there's always a first time.  And if it gives you piece of mind . . ."  This was definitely reassuring to me! 2. Dr. #2 and the pathologist both recommended excision.  The Dr. had called the pathologist since the report was so vague.  Since there was only part of a radial scar in one core, they both recommended excision.  Dr. #2 said better to be safe than sorry and that I had "very complex" breast tissue in the area.  Dr. #1 also mentioned I had architectural distortion on the mammogram.  I definitely have very dense, fibrocystic breasts and this increased greatly since my last mammo 2 years ago.  3. Dr. #3, the one who will be doing my surgery, said it's best to remove all radial scars.  I meet with him this morning for a pre-op and I'm trying to come up with my list of questions to ask him about the surgery (wire plus excision).  I'm hoping he'll do IV sedation instead of general anesthesia.  I'll let you know if he says anything interesting this morning.  Did you have any atypia?  I'm going to ask him what percentage of cases like mine come back with cancer. I decided to go for the surgery yesterday and actually feel good about it now.  I think a scar on my chest and a few days of pain are worth not having to wonder if something was missed in there.  The area is about 2 inches above my nipple so I'm going to ask if the scar will be there or if they'll do it along the arreola.
Posts.Title: Radial Scar ?'s cemjo3 marie5890

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2009 10:44PM - edited Aug 13, 2009 10:44PM by Juliecc How frustrating for you!  I would definitely be pushy about this and get the mammogram as soon as possible.  I guess with possible IBC they diagnose it with a punch biopsy?  The whole process of mammograms, sonograms, consults, authorizations, etc. can seem to take forever.  I hope they move fast for you so you can get some answers.  Is your doc sending you for a diagnostic mammogram?  Restate all your symptoms to the radiologist also.  It's definitely better to be pushy than go with the program. I'm sorry you're in such pain.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 05:03PM Juliecc wrote: I would definitely do the excisional biopsy.  I've always read that when there is atypia, there is a 30% chance that there is something nearby.  I'm getting an excisional on a radial star Thursday even though there is only a 5% chance.  I'm sure a second opinion will tell you the same thing but it doesn't hurt to ask.  I think that peace of mind is definitely worth a scar.   I hope everything turns out benign for you.  Put atypia in the search box and you'll get a lot of information.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 12:05AM Juliecc wrote: I'm home from the vacuum assisted stereotactic biopsy and it was awesome!  Seriously I should have never read all the bad stories on the internet.  It took at least 45 minutes to an hour, though, of different compresions and then getting off the table for a quick diagnostic mammo, then more compressions on the table before they were happy they were going to hit the right spot. My cluster was only 4 mm amongst my very dense breast tissue so it was more difficult.   I only said ow twice when they stuck the lidocaine in but it only hurt for a few seconds.  After that I just felt a little tugging.  The length of time from the lidocaine to using the machine was less than 5 minutes!  They took my samples out to x-ray them and 3 of the 12 cores had the microcalcifications in them so they hit the spot. They showed me the before and after mammograms afterwards and pointed out the titanium marker.  I have an ice pack but I feel totally fine.  They said it might ache later like someone punched me in the boob.  I'm going out to dinner with the BF with the ice pack in my bra :-)  Make sure you buy your own because the one they give you is tiny and doesn't stay cold long.  The doc said to eat with my left hand tonight but I'm not very good at following directions like that.  :-p Mommysta, I hope it goes easy for you too!  Try not to worry!  It really was easy.  I would have no qualms if they told me I had to have another one.  Limit your fluids tomorrow so you don't have to pee.  Also, wear long pants/sweatpants and socks because it was a little cold in there! I should get the results tomorrow afternoon or Friday.
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 02:50PM Juliecc wrote: I agree that it's good to put positive stories out there!  I was sooo nervous from reading too many experiences.  I said the actual procedure took 5 minutes but seriously I think the core needle was in there for less than a minute.  I must have asked the doctor twice, "Your done?  That's it?"  They did x-ray the samples first real quick before declaring they were done.  I surely thought maybe he took a small number of samples but he took 12 in less than a minute!  I was actually quite interested in all the technical aspects of it all. So the morning after, my breast is only sore if I push on it (so obviously I just won't do that!)  I could also feel it was a little heavier.  I don't really see much bruising around the steristrips either.  I'm heading to work in a good mood :-)  Good luck today, mommysta!

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 10:28AM - edited Aug 9, 2009 10:29AM by Juliecc I just had mine done on Wednesday on one side only.  My doctor told me to wait at least a couple of days before going to the gym and to take it easy,  For the day of the biopsy, my doc even said to eat with my left hand because you'd be moving your pec muscle which could cause bleeding.  I took Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday off from the gym.  I have no pain at all now but I still chose to just do the recumbent bike and leg weights only.  I'll start arm weights in a couple more days.  I'll also hold off on jogging for a few days and do incline walking instead.  All of this is not because of pain but I really don't want a hematoma forming in there!  As for the eliptical, can you do it without the arm motions for a few days?  If you use your legs only, your chest doesn't get jostled too much! For a few hours after my biopsy, it felt like someone punched me in the upper arm.  That pain went away after about 3 hours.  My breast started to ache 5 hours after and I was icing it alot.  I worked the next day and it was totally fine.  I snuck an ice pack in there every once in awhile because it was soothing. Sorry you have to get both sides done!

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2014 09:30PM - edited Jul 28, 2014 09:30PM by Juliecc Everyone's situation is different!  I have no regrets about getting a BMX.  My tumor was very close to my chest wall on the left side.  Radiation can cause heart and lung problems and I didn't want to risk it.  I also have a long history of biopsies and call backs.  I think it's important for a woman to really take the time to think through her decision.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2014 05:36AM Juliecc wrote: I had a bilateral MX with TE placement outpatient.  It was a 6 hour surgery but I still went home that evening.  I didn't have pain or nausea issues so it was totally doable.  The PS used Exparel for pain.  It is injected at the end of surgery in the surgical site and it provides 3 days of pain relief.  Ask about that.  Also ask for an ear patch you put on the morning of surgery and tell your anesthesiologist to give you something to avoid nausea.  I woke up feeling great.

So maybe driving, dinner, and frolicking wasn't the best idea in the world but it was worth it :-)  For the first 3 hours I didn't have any pain in my breast but strangly my upper arm hurt like when you get a flu shot or if someone punched me there.  That pain went away and then at the 5 hour mark by breast was aching and still is.  Totally tolerable though.  Still have the ice pack going on.  Time for bed, Good luck tomorrow, mommysta.  Tell us how it went!

Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2009 10:31PM - edited Aug 21, 2009 11:50AM by Juliecc Hang in there Barbgale and Elizabeth.  The stereotactic for calcs wasn't that bad at all (just the lidocaine shot hurt for a few seconds) and the excisional biopst today was even easier!  It was my first surgery so I was quite nervous. Mommysta, here's the play by play of my excisional biopsy for you:  By the way I had a headache all day probably due to no caffeine, water, or food.  They did the wire localization in a mammogram room with a rolling chair.  There were 3 people there.  They did all mammogram compressions while I was sitting.  They took a couple of views and then while compressed, gave me a lidocaine shot.  They then inserted the hollow needle and took a couple more mammo views.  I felt tugging when they played with the needle but not pain.  It took them a few minutes to get the needle right where they wanted it.  Then they stuck the wire in and took 2 more views.  They put the needle through the side even though my stereo was through the top.  They taped the wire down with a gauze pad on top and a lady walked me to the elevators and up to the surgery floor.  I was offered a blanket and I took it because it was freezing there!  I had to wait 45 minutes or more in the waiting room until a pre op bed was available. I had my own little room for pre op where I'd spend the next 4 hours!  I had my vitals taken, medical history questions asked, went to the bathroom twice, they did a urine pregnancy test, and then they inserted an IV (no drugs just fluids).  I took about a 2 hour nap which was awesome! Finally 1 and a half hours past my scheduled time, the surgeon came in the see if I had any questions.  Then the anesthesiologist came in and I told him I wanted twighlight sleep.  Everyone was fine with that. Next a nurse put a shot in my IV to relax me (verced I think).  Then I got wheeled to the OR.  I noticed it was big and drab.  There were 3 people across the room fiddling with equipment.  After that, I don't remember a thing!  I don't remember the surgeon walking in or seeing the anesthesiologist.  I don't remember being wheeled to recovery either.  It was fantastic.  I stayed there for 45 minutes and they gave me apple juice.  My sister in law showed up to take me home.  I was fully alert and dressed myself with no problem.  I only have a 4 by 4 inch gauze pad covered by an even bigger square piece of tape,  I can't take a real shower for 48 hours!  We went through a drive through and I devoured a chicken sandwich.  I was starving!  I don't have hardly any pain right now but I think I'll fill my vicoden prescription just in case. The surgeon didn't mark the box about using ice packs but I am anyway!  I hope that's ok.  I didn't even see the surgeon afterward but a nurse said he said it all went well.  No pain yet but I remember my breast starting to ache 5 hours after the stereotactic biopsy.  It was tolerable though.  I think that's it!  I finally got my first surgery ever out of the way :-)
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 12:32PM Juliecc wrote: Good to hear from you mommysta!  I'm sorry about your mri experience.  I've never had one of those.  They should tell you what they are doing to you! Will they be using general or twilight sleep for you next Thursday?  Will you get to choose?  I can't speak for everyone but I'm really glad I did the twighlight sleep.  I was totally asleep and then woke right up feeling great!  I didn't feel drugged or anything.  No nausea at all.  I even drove myself to CVS 3 hours later to get my vicoden in case I needed it. Good luck and I hope they find nothing more than the ADH. I think I'll get my results next week.  I am going to enjoy my weekend for sure!  I'm even going out with the BF tonight.  I drove the kids to school and everything has been easy.  I have to remember to take it easy even though nothing hurts.  Tomorrow I get to take the gauze off to take a normal shower.  I took a lower half shower this morning :-).  I can't wait to see what the excision looks like underneath.  I'd peak but it's taped down pretty good and I shouldn't mess with it.  My mom lives a couple hours away and I haven't told her I was having the surgery.  I didn't want her to freak out and drive up here.  I'll call her today and tell her I did it and that it was easy.  Should be interesting.  I'll probably be in trouble with her!
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 09:13AM Juliecc wrote: Thanks Fergy.  I'm thinking my results will be benign since they took out 12 vacuum assisted samples.  It's difficult when you have one doctor saying "wait and see" and another saying "get it excised".  I'm glad I did the latter.  I'm not thinking about the results, just about feeling better after the surgery.  I think I have a UTI.  Ugh.  I'm getting tired of going to the doctor so much!  It will be about my 10th trip this summer!  Thank you for your encouraging words!

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 09:04AM - edited Oct 29, 2014 09:05AM by Juliecc With an Oncotype Dx score of 12, I was told 8% chance of recurrence within 10 years with Tamoxifen for 10 years.  I didn't do chemo or radiation.  Chemo might have given me about a 2% benefit but the risks would outweigh the benefits in my case.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2015 11:05PM Juliecc wrote: I had a radial scar removed back in 2009. It was discovered during a stereotactic biopsy for microcalcifications. The excisional biopsy surgery was very easy and the results were totally benign. The surgery was less than 30 minutes and hurt less than the original biopsy. I read a lot about radial scars back then and there were arguments about whether it increased your risk of breast cancer or not. I was diagnosed with BC in 2014 but in my OTHER breast. I don't think the radial scar had anything to do with me getting cancer years later in the other one. Best wishes to you.
Posts.Title: 1 inch Radial Scar w/ Calcification..could it be cancer? Dearjaimee Dearjaimee

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2015 08:30AM Juliecc wrote: Your doctor would have to approve getting your other side mammogramed which might be tough. I remember over the years I was denied when I asked my doctor for a diagnostic mammogram instead of a regular one when I felt a lump, or they were sonograming one side and not the other. It's worth asking for if it gives you peace of mind. I thik they don't want to expose you to excess radiaion if it isn't warranted.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2014 01:29PM Juliecc wrote: Blessings, I used most of your post and put this on my facebook.  Thank you!  It is being very well received: Breast cancer 101 time. Feel free to share this post. Breast cancer is a very sneaky disease. I was diagnosed earlier this year with IDC (Invasive Ductal Carcinoma) and had a bilateral mastectomy and reconstruction. Unfortunately, I will always live with the fear of metastasis. During my last reconstruction surgery in August, I had 2 areas biopsied and they were ok. Now I have several new hard bumps we are watching that are probably just scar tissue or dissolvable sutures. I am checked every 3 months and will be on Tamoxifen for 10 years. "Approximately 5% to 10% of breast cancers are metastatic at diagnosis; of these, approximately one-fifth will survive 5 years. Depending on prognostic factors, up to 30% of node-negative and up to 70% of node-positive breast cancers will relapse." Yes even stage one, node negative breast cancer can recur as stage 4. There is no cure for metastatic breast cancer. So breast cancer is always on my mind, every hour of the day it pops up in my head. Hopefully that will get better as time passes. I really appreciate all the love and support from my friends and family this year! You have all been amazing. Remember 1 in 8 of us will be diagnosed in our lifetimes so please check yourselves often. The earlier you are diagnosed, the better your prognosis. We are now in breast cancer awareness month and we will be seeing pink ribbons everywhere, from our bucket of KFC chicken, to our box of cereal. Here is a post I'd like to share from a fellow breast cancer survivor: As many of you begin to participate in the Annual “Breast Cancer Awareness” activities coming up, I just ask you to please consider these things: 1. Does the activity TRIVIALIZE breast cancer? NOT GOOD! This is a very serious issue. 2. Does the activity SEXUALIZE breast cancer? NOT GOOD! There is nothing sexy about breast cancer. 3. Does the activity generate income to be donated to a reputable organization that provides direct services to women in need? GREAT! Low income patients need all the help they can get. 4. Does the activity generate income to be donated to a reputable organization that funds research for a breast cancer CURE? GREAT! We all have “awareness”… what we need is a CURE. 5. If you put a “Pinkwashed” product in your shopping cart, have you checked to see exactly how much money from that sale is donated, and the name of the organization where the proceeds are donated? GREAT! If it is not stated, then the MANUFACTURER is making money off the misery of breast cancer patients everywhere. NOT GOOD! Pink ribbon advertising is not enough.
Posts.Title: Brace yourself, September is slipping, inexorably, to Foctober weesa Blessings2011

Posts.Title: My wait is over...wanted to share good news. CAmomto2 covertanjou

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 07:26PM Juliecc wrote: Hang in there!  It sounds like they are moving quickly which is great.  It's been over 7 weeks since my diagnostic mammo and I'm still waiting for the final results.  My understanding is that a Birads 4 warrants "further investigation or biopsy" but it doesn't necessarily mean they think it's cancer!  My mammo was a Birads 4 with microcalcifications.  I had a stereotactic biopsy and there wasn't any cancer - just a radial scar.  They did an excisional on the 20th just to check the area to be sure and I'm still waiting for that report.  I keep hearing 80% of biopsies are benign and I would think that all of those who ended up with biopsies were Birads 4 or 5.
